content.description: Yellow is a V0+ with two good solid crimps and then big move into a crack (can’t really see it when on the wall) and then climb up and top out to the right. The blue holds make it a V2 variation with a quick move to the yellow right hand start and then follow the yellow route. The bottom blue circle is the foot.
content.protection: 1 or 2 pads and a spotter. We had 1 pad.
content.location: The right side of Crinoid Cove. Around the corner of The Surfing Raptor.

content.description: Left of shark week. The harder line up the middle. Pop to a good right hand side pull halfway up.
Start at the far right with both hands in the two small pockets. Traverse to the left until you reach corner where most people will down climb to get off the boulder. Top out from there.
content.location: Start is on the side of the boulder facing the Giddy Up boulder.

content.description: Start on the same hands as Everything is Matter. Move up to a gaston with your left to a pinch on a tooth. Get a hand on a less-than-ideal crimp and finish with a topout.
content.location: Same start as Everything is Matter. Runs vertically between Turd Burglar and Chundercling.

content.description:
Problem working the left most arete of the Crinoid Cove Boulder.

 Decent exposure on this route as a few of the moves have your weight shifting out left into a sloped drop, however the holds are great and it is a well-sequenced relatively static line.

 Sit start from the shelf, moving up to the jug then trend left and in to hit a small undercling on the corner. Pull into the right sidepull at the base of the flake and then tense in to hit the edge up and around the arete. Hit another great sidepull and top out directly over the arete using good hands.
content.location: Sit start on the lowest left shelf, same as Gaston Bone

content.description: Long but secure moves to the top, fun top out.
content.location: Left crimp and right slot just above and right of detached block.

content.description: Somewhat contrived. Stay in narrow lane, don't use holds out left on "Shark Week". Start on jug and climb straight up blank steepness through a couple small holds.
content.location: Start in middle of steepest part of the boulder, just right of shark week.

content.description: Hey all, there was no description of this route despite some of the holds having chalk already on them. My guess is that it's either been worked on and not posted/sent (top jugs have no chalk) and/or the holds on this route are used on lines to the left and right of this problem. That said, if you know someone that has climbed this before me, send me a message and I'll change the FA accordingly. (10/3/20)Start on the relatively easy bottom holds and work your way into the leaning rail just above. There's the 'triangle' holds for your right and the crux is figuring out wha tot do with your left hand... many options there, the fun is finding out what works best. Throw to a right hand (side pull?) that fits a full pad and then bring your left hand up to the hold directly left of it. Finish on bucket and top out.
content.location: Crinoid Cove, left of Shark Week. This appears to use some holds for Turd Burglar but is distinctly more difficult.

content.description: Start on obvious flat jug follow good holds straight up the face to top out.
content.location: Down the hill to the left of Ape Index.

content.description: Start with left hand on a geometric ledge and right on an incut within the seam above the rightmost death block (now crushed into a nice landing by Crinoid Temptation’s first ascentionist) on the left side of the boulder. Place a high foot and launch past Everything is Matter and Rest Day, Best Day's rail to dunk on the good spot on the lip. Mantle on secure holds and reflect on the vast oceans that once occupied the Ohio Valley.
content.protection: Mega pads and spotters unless you can fly
content.location: The start holds are to the left of Turd Burglar and to the right of Gaston Bone and Crinoid Temptations

content.description: I didn't see any chalk on this route, and the landing is really bad so I may have been the first to put this up, not sure though. Some techy moves up a block. Possibly some loose holds, be careful. Also, top out is scary.
content.location: Left side of the boulder, sit start on some light colored ledges.

content.description: This is a long extension into Feather Star. Start by using a left side pull and a flake, then traverse right into Feather Star.
content.location: It starts just to the left of Rest Day, Best Day, and finishes where Feather Star ends.

content.description: This is an extension to Feather Star. Start using the same starting hold for Shark Week. Traverse to the right to link into Feather Star
content.location: Start at Shark Week and finish in Feather Star

content.description: The easiest line to the top. Follow the flakes to the lip.
content.protection: Multiple pads. Its a bit tall.

content.description: Traverse left and dyno to topout.
Microcrimp left hand, and right hand on a small nub pinch. First move crux to a right hand sidepull. Continue straight up avoiding the arete to the left. Potential for a hard low start.
content.location: Left side of the Crinoid cave.

content.description: Right of shark week.  Right hand Undercling to left hand funk knob to jug rail.

Start on The Surfing Raptor and continue around the arete, traversing low with your feet on the ramp.  Once you encounter a good slot and left hand side pull pinch, cross up to a crimp, then move left to a ledge.  Traverse left into Gaston Bone and top out on the arete.
content.protection: 3-4 Crash pads.  The landing at the end of the boulder when you move to top out is covered in pointed rocks.  Spotters to move the pads as you traverse are helpful as well.
content.location: The boulder starts on the lower left end of the Crinoid Cove boulder and traverses all the way to the right.

content.description: Same start as Riptide. Pull left to undercling, make big move to slopers and top out.
content.location: Just to the left of the prominent prow of the Crinoid boulder.

content.description: A fun boulder with some of the best cluster of lines on the Western Wetlands. The boulder gets sun and is one of the first to dry after rain. The landings are generally good with only a few sketch landings.
